awd_titl_txt: Targeted Infusion Project: Integrating Mobile Computing and Security into a Computer Science Curriculum
awd_abstract_narration:
Mobile platforms have become extremely popular among users and an important platform for developers. New privacy and security issues arise with the prevalence of mobile computing since mobile devices often store tremendous amount of personal, financial and commercial data, and therefore attract both targeted and mass-scale attacks. To meet the growing demand for mobile computing and security professionals, it is vitally important to provide education in mobile computing and security to students in computer science and other related disciplines. The overall goal of the project at North Carolina A&T University is to address this workforce need by developing course modules in mobile computing and security. The modules will be integrated into existing Computer Science courses such as computer programming, software development, operating systems, and information assurance courses. Each course module includes a tutorial, presentation slides, hands-on labs and/or case studies, and test questions. To actively disseminate these new course materials, two faculty summer development workshops will be offered, as well as a mobile programming contest for undergraduate students.

This project seeks to strengthen the Computer Science program at North Carolina A&T University by updating the Computer Science curriculum to address state-of-art technology. Students will be more competitive in the workforce and well-prepared for graduate studies in the areas of mobile computing and security. Therefore, this project will increase the education and career opportunities of African American students. This project will also develop and strengthen the University's Center for Cyber Defense, a Center of Academic Excellence in Information Assurance Education designated by the National Security Agency and the Department of Homeland Security, by expanding its education and research programs. Societal benefits of this project include increased educational materials and improved opportunities for training students to address mobile computing and security challenges.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

inst.inst_name: North Carolina Agricultural & Technical State University

por.por_cntn:
Through the NSF HBCU-UP Targeted Infusion Project: Developing a Health Informatics Security and Privacy Program, a Bachelor of Science in Computer Science concentration in Health Informatics Security and Privacy (HISP) was established in North Carolina A&T State University. This was the joint effort of the Departments of Computer Science, Mathematics and Management. In the effort of developing this interdisciplinary program, a new course “COMP323 Introduction to Health Information Systems” was developed in the Department of Computer Science, a new course “COMP410 Mathematics for Health Informatics” was developed in the Department of Mathematics, and an existed course in the Department of Management “MIS640 MIS special topics was modified to include topics on business practices relating to health informatics security and privacy. Three course modules on health informatics security and privacy were also developed and integrated into the existing computer security and information assurance courses in the Department of Computer Science. The course modules include “Health Information Assurance and Security”, “Access Control in Healthcare Information Systems”, and “XML Security in Health Information Systems”. The curriculum model and instruction materials can be adopted by faculty at other colleges and universities. This project also fosters research in the areas of health informatics security and privacy, software engineering for health information systems, etc.

This project increased the educational and career opportunities for African American students. This project has allowed students to develop awareness of and interest in Healthcare Informatics careers, and as a result of this project, have avenues for pursuing this career field. Therefor this project helped to expand the workforce pipeline in healthcare informatics. This project provided student participants with research experiences and provided students with topics for Masters Project, Masters Thesis, and independent study courses. This project also provided undergraduate students with research experiences. This project provided students with experiences of publishing papers in conferences and journals, presenting at conferences, and collaborating with other students in conducting research.  The project results have been disseminated through peer-reviewed journal and conference publications, presentations at conferences.

 


Last Modified: 09/07/2018
Modified by: Xiaohong Yuan
